reviewText:
To start off, I can't say that this is my favorite NFS game of all time, but it is certainly up there. I have been a NFS fan for a long time, dating back to the good old PS2 days with Most Wanted and Carbon. So far no other NFS game, in my opinion, has been better than those, but Hot Pursuit is definitely in the top 10 on my list for racing games, and here's why.

PROS:

The graphics are fantastic. The car models are awesome as always, and the scenery is beautiful. Yes, scenery especially matters to me because I want to be able to go for a nice drive, if that's what I'm in the mood for. It looks great at 200+ MPH too! Now don't expect Metro: Last Light graphics, but it really is a nice looking game.

There are quite a few cars as well. I can't say for sure how many there are, but it's certainly enough to keep you busy with trying certain races with different cars or just taking them for a spin. Not to mention that for every normal car in the game there is a cop car counterpart, with the addition of a couple! So if driving at 250 MPH on a freeway with sirens on sounds fun to you, please give this a try! But what about how they handle?

I personally enjoy how the cars handle in this. It is NOT a simulator in any way. It is arcade style racing with easy drifting so you can boost into those corners like a boss without losing tons of speed or control. To me it seems like all the cars handle in a very similar fashion, but I actually don't mind it. I don't think this type of racing is for everyone however, but it's not hard at all to get used to. Remember that this game is all about going fast to evade cops or bust racers using special abilities, so you can't be completely focused on realistic driving. But that brings me to another thing I love about this.

In the game, whether you are a racer or a cop, you have access to EMPs, spike strips, roadblocks, extreme turbo, and more. All these make the game more exciting and tense. If you are a racer, you can drop spike strips on cops OR other racers and use EMPs to pass someone, and if you are a cop, you use all of these to take down racers. I especially enjoyed the cop career more because it is really fun to smash into other cars and send them into a barrel roll or other cool crashes.

NEUTRAL:

The free roam is one thing I always want in a racing game. Yes, Hot Pursuit does have it, but I feel that it is missing content. Being able to free roam as a racer, you would expect to occasionally run into a police car and get into some sort of epic chase, or vice versa being a cop, but sadly that just isn't the case. There aren't even any collectables! I guess the free roam in Hot Pursuit is pretty much there to test out cars or just go for a nice ride. So yes, it's nice to have, but it lacks content.

The menus are sub-par. You can very easily tell that it is more suited for consoles. While I strongly recommend using a controller for this game anyways, the least they could have done was provide a more intuitive menu for us PC gamers.

CONS:

With the exception of changing the color of the car, there is NO customization. I guess I spoiled" myself with the feature of customizing back when I played on the PS2 because now every NFS game that has come out recently has zero options to customize
date: and it has been very disappointing. I don't know why they ever took it out.\n\nNow that I think about it
recommended:
the menu tutorial at the very beginning of the game is really dumb and unskippable. It's like they expect you to know absolutely nothing about how a menu works. It is completely useless and takes a couple minutes. Can't you just let us play the game already?

TL;DR:

NFS: Hot Pursuit is a really fun game with very nice graphics

One thing I have become increasingly frustrated with when playing racing games these past few years is that developers seem to throw more and more crap between you and actually racing with every new release. Hot Pursuit may well be the pinacle of this.

The races themselves are a lot of fun. The cars have a good sense of speed, the sound is great, the crashes have impact and the game is very pretty all around. The problem is that you won't actually get to experience these things much. The majority of your time will be spent watching unskippable cutscenes, loading times, logging in on your EA account (with no way to save your login details so you don't have to enter them every singe time you start the game) or being harassed by the game to check out its totally cool social hub feature where it pretends to be Facebook. And God help you if the EA servers happen to be down, in which case the game will try connecting to them at the start of the game and the end of every single bloody 2 minute race, taking 10 seconds each time. It really adds up to the point where 50% of your time with Hot Pursuit is spent looking at ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you really don't want to see.

reviewText:
The Original Car Chase game, revamped... At least that's what I expected. Back in the '98 version it was a great fun game of racing vs your opponents, and the police - avoiding insanely high speed crashes and shaving that couple of seconds extra off a track, or getting a little nudge in at just the right moment, to win a race.

Fast-Forward many generations of game development and hardware cycles, and we have the reboot.

Initially it looks promising, graphically it's a lot nicer, the tracks are interesting, and they've kept the tradition of high-risk shortcuts to get to the end faster - but this is one of the things that shows up the games truly hideous faults.

1- The enemies are scripted to keep up, not actually racing around the track as they look, but constantly teleporting around the track to be close to you. No matter how good you are, you cannot get more than a few seconds lead, even on a car you just saw crash into a virtually impossible situation, while you are at max boost - he'll be on your tail and overtaking the instant you take a corner less than optimally.

2- Speaking of cornering - it cannot be done without a horrible skid mechanic. You just dont get to keep control of the car. At the time the game was made, drifting was very trendy, and the makers seem to have decided to make it mandatory for every car, every race.

3- The collision detection is horrible for such a high end racing game. Often you pass another vehicle, or other obsticle, knowing you've cut it close, but also knowing you've missed, when suddenly the game decides you've hit, and not just clipped something, but catastrophically flipped your car and ruined your race.

4- Hardware support. After a few months of having this game, my nephew loved playing it for fun, so despite not being able to forgive it's foibles, I kept the game, but after I changed some stuff on my system, it's refused to run ever since. Gets to the loading screen, CTD with no error report.

RIP NFS memories.

reviewText: Hot Pursuit is a Need for Speed game in name only. This blisteringly fast racer has more in common with developer Criterion Games' own Burnout series than it does with any previous Need for Speed offering, despite lacking a number of features that are commonly associated with Burnout games. This isn't a game in which you're rewarded for crashing spectacularly or for jumping through billboards, but it is a game that encourages you to drive dangerously and to take down your opponents by any means necessary. The option to play both as illegal racers and as the cops that are chasing them brings some much-needed variety to the action, while spike strips, road blocks, and other satisfying countermeasures ensure that Hot Pursuit doesn't feel quite like any racer that you've played before. Regardless of whether your interest in Hot Pursuit stems from a love of Need for Speed, Burnout, or neither, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
This 2010 comeback of the Hot Pursuit series, developed by Criterion, is a great example of how not to reboot a game. Thankfully this game turned out to be very fun.

In short, Criterion turned Need For Speed into a full-on car combat game. For those of you who were wanting a faithful follow up to Blackbox's 2003 Playstation 2 classic Hot Pursuit 2 will be greatly disappointed. If you come from Burnout 3 Takedown or Revenge roots, then this will be a tough call as well since iconic fictitious car brands and super accessible arcade driving physics are out. For those who love car combat or even kart and anti-gravity racers sub-genres may want to look into this game.

Despite the fact that Hot Pursuit 2010 is rooted in reality, the core gameplay is about cops versus racers equipped with weapon loadouts duking it out on mostly point-to-point courses. There are a lot of mind games to be had, from intentionally driving backwards to strategically cancelling enemy EMP blasts.

The driving physics are heavy and boat-like compared to past Criterion titles, but you can still swing your car left and right easily enough to stay in the realm of arcade driving. Once you engage in a drift, your car does feel significantly lighter so you can nudge your car mid-drift to slip through cracks in traffic obstacles. Swerving to dodge sliding spike strips isn't a trivial task however.

As with any Hot Pursuit entry, you should expect to find plenty of exotic sports cars and super cars. What is interesting is that Criterion managed to fit in some very modest cars like the Evo, WRX STi and RX-8 without feeling out of place in a roster filled with Lamborghini and Porsche. You will be drifting on dirt and wet roads in the Evo and weaving past city cars in a police issued WRX STi. Speaking of police liveries, they look particularly amazing on the entire roster of the Law side. They don't all come in black and white either, expect some true to life palettes like peacekeeper blue, ranger green and even a patriotic flag on the GT40.

2010 saw the release of Hot Pursuit by Criterion as well as Blur by Bizarre and Split/Second by Black Rock. While I do approve of this one-off reboot, some people may disagree because this does effectively kill off any hopes of a new Burnout game. Whether you love or hate this game, what is universally agreeable is that 2010 was a great year for racing game fans who crave for the return of action packed alternative racing.

reviewText: Need for Speed: Hot Pursuit is a really good racing game with great graphics and gameplay. The only flaw is that there is no opportunity to tune your car like in Need for Speed Underground 2.When the online modes work, they really sing, allowing for hours to slip away into tons of entertaining crashes and near-misses. It offers fast and furious oldschool-action, plenty of mileage and an overall good ride. A lack of modes, some rather bland race types, the always present rubberband-A.I. and a lack of challenge bothered me. But overall I liked what Hot Pursuit had to offer. A lot!

reviewText:
Usually I don't like racing video games. When I was younger me and my brother used to play the demo of Need for Speed Hot Pursuit 2 from a CD-ROM which we got from a cereal box and we had wicked fun. When I saw that there's a reboot of the Hot Pursuit series I was sceptic but the child in me said that I should buy it for old times sake.

Man I'm glad I did, it took me only a few minutes to set up a game and start driving I've instantly felt the nostalgic feeling, the same thrill of playing the game. The gameplay is smooth, polished and simple. There's no car customization and no story It's just pure old-fashioned driving fun. The graphics and cars are gorgeous and it runs well even on a laptop. I highly recommend it to anybody who is just looking for an arcade-type simple racing game to have fun and just relax, I think Need for Speed Hot Pursuit is the best choice on the market.

reviewText:
Received as part of the EA humble bundle as I havnt played a NFS game since NFS: Underground I was looking forward to the experience.  What I got was a highly polished, shiny console port with all the fun and excitement of a coma.

The Pros:
The graphics are lovely even on my very average gaming laptop (Quad i7, Radeon mobility 5830) and the selection of cars is everything you could ever wish to drive in the real world.  The cars feel quite quick with all the motion blur and the roads aren‚Äôt too busy so there is less chance of frustration in that department.  Sound is pretty good but after a short while you notice there are only so many different engine sounds in the game...

The Cons:
As usual with EA games, LOADS of hoops to jump and advertising to watch.  Login's, 'dont turn off your computer while saving' screens and un-skippable marketing material mean waiting a good 3 minutes before actually driving anything!  Throughout the game there are loads of these tedious video's telling you how to drive, how the driving modes work (of which there are loads) and every time you win a new car (which is almost every race) you have to sit through a 30 sec video of it spinning and flashing!  Everything just takes soooo long...  Even the ill conceived open world landscape is empty and pointless.

Once you finally start to race the problems really begin.  I know NFS has never been a driving sim like Gran Tourismo but there have to be limits.  No matter what you drive, all the cars handle the same only with different max speeds and even then it doesn‚Äôt really matter.  The balancing for the AI is so severe that even if you crash throughout a race, the opposition is always just around the corner.  The same is true if you have a perfect race, a crash just before the finish will result in a 5th place finish as you CANNOT escape the opposition... ever...  The game play becomes monotonous and boring so fast i'd had enough after an hour of play each session.

There are countless other niggles but it all adds up to yet another poor racing arcade game.  Stick to the old ones if simple fun is even slightly important to you.

reviewText:
In short do I recommend this game? Yes I do. However I say this yes with a bit of a weight. You're going to have to like the game quite a bit to stomach the loading screens (and auto log into screen)...

Anyway,

In somewhat of a glorified version of Need For Speed : Hot Pursuit 2 - this Need for Speed : Hot Pursuit is a big update from the previously mentioned game. The graphics have been significantly upgraded and a lot of appealing cars have been added. Career is essentially overlooking the main map and choosing either police or racer events. Some events are a bit weird I found as I was finding myself in a time trial racing in a cop car. It made sense in a way sure you cut off some suspect at the end but it felt a bit gimmicky to me (I've mostly skipped those races and only done them when I had to progress to new events).

As a racer your given abilities just like the police have. Jammer of course sort of stuns the HUD of your police car or disables cops abilities. There is a spike strip also available for racers as well as EMP. Racers also have the ability to have turbo which just sends the car flying.

Police are able to use spike strips, call for a helicopter that can deploy a spike strip, call for a road block, or use an EMP as well. To be honest the EMP just locks on a removes some of the racers health... don't really like it. I personally liked back from NFS HP 2 you could call for a single car backup that would help slow down or ram the car.

Driving is alright. This is as arcade as it can get. It seems they took Shift's 2 drift mechanism or something along those lines and made it the racing mechanic. Literally every turn you take I guess is mean to be a high speed drift. Again, this is where the original NFS HP 2 on PS2 or xbox was really good. Shift 2 for sure though takes the cake when it comes to driving games.

Do I recommend this game? Well... not whole heartidly. I do like it but the loading screens, autolog, and the driving doesn't quite agree with me - so much that I'd rather be playing the game I mentioned earlier. The abilities are cool but I just don't feel the user interface is all the greatest either. No two player? Really? Of course you can play online but playing with a friend doesn't happen in this one. The issue also here is when you collide with a car - it doesn't feel like a collision. I don't feel the angle I hit at (P.I.T manouever doesn't really work) or how hard I hit properly registers. There's also the point where you can't simply play a quick race and adjust how many spike strips or road blocks you get. It's simply career with event races. This is why the game sort of has that gimmick feel to it. I feel a lot more could have been done here but perhaps given time constraints weren't enough.

I'll recommend it but can't give it the highest of scores.

7.1/10

reviewText:
This game is like a gorgeous airhead.  It's pretty, but it's also pretty shallow.  Actually, it's like a gorgeous airhead who won't shut up about her favorite reality TV show, but we'll get to that (the cutscenes issue) in a minute.

The graphics in the game are undoubtedly beautiful.  I don't think anyone could argue against that point.  However, the gameplay itself is ultimately fairly hollow and weak.

Admittedly, I haven't gotten that far into the game, but from the outset, there's really not much differentiation among the cars.  Or at least, given the events I used them in, there didn't feel to be a ton of difference.  The cop side felt like the most fun because you got to smash into other racer cars and take them out.  The racer side was just the typical stuff.  As you progress up both ladders (which you can play simultaneously -- which is weird), you also unlock various gadgets for different events.  Spike traps, roadblocks, EMP blasts, helicopters, turbo boosts, blah blah blah.  It's supposed to spice up the gameplay, but it didn't do a ton for me.

Why?  Well, the game just feels...hollow.  For example, there's no storyline at all, so you have nothing compelling you forward.  Now, the other NFS game that I have on Steam is Undercover, and I'll be the first to admit that it's not like the story there was one for the ages.  It featured weak acting, overblown dialogue, etc.  But at least it provided you with...something.  Plus, you could customize your cars.  Yes, that's right. There's no customization in this game.  At all.  Well, not beyond selecting one of a limited number of paint colors for your car when you're a racer.

In this game, you unlock vehicles, but unlike most other racing games I've played, you have no ability to tune or otherwise customize them.  You're also limited in your choices based on the event you're in.  You don't buy cars, either.  You just unlock them when you level up...and that's it.  You get some voiceover reading you PR copy about the car that sounds like it was written by the manufacturer's ad department.

The cars themselves handled...so-so.  They don't seem to grip the road particularly effectively.  You slide around a LOT.  Now, it's not as bad as, say, flooring it in a Forza game, but then, this game isn't supposed to be anything like a Forza game.  It's an arcade racer, not a sim.  The end result is that the cars felt kind of annoying to drive much of the time.

There are two other really annoying features, though.  First is the game's built-in Facebook-like Autolog."  Some idiot suit probably made the game developers include this

reviewText:
With the exclusion to Motor City Online, I played every single NFS piece. While I hated so many of them, and praised with much glory High Stakes, Porsche Unleashed, Hot Pursuit 2 and Most Wanted, I say with confidence that this one is the best NFS I've ever played. Period. Nothing to question about.

Visuals of the game are glorious, enough you'll love Seacrest County and will be exploring every scenery of it each race. But while the game isn't all graphics, the gameplay is also beautiful, and while you may find drifting pretty much like a hack and slash game which you press a button to backflip kill someone, you'll need to skill yourself in it and get better lines and better exit speeds as you play it. I guess the biggest fault of the game is the lack of a skill level on single-player, which is natural if you think this game is made to be played online with your friends.

The car list is certainly beautiful and pretty wide, ranging from entry-level sports cars such as the beautiful Porsche Boxster and the Mazda RX8, from icons of Japanese and North American automotive industry to the legendary Le Mans racer McLaren F1 (not the GTR though, a pity) and the overrated beast Bugatti Veyron SS, and the best: All of them in a similar playing field. While you'll soon discover Revent√≥n is a monster in it's class, picking a similar Lamborghini will get you covered to match the concept bull aswell.

Well, realism, if you want it, go to iRacing. You'll be drifting a Ford GT at 150mph while the turbo is on (don't question how does this turbo works or go mechanical into it, just accept it) avoiding a spike strip that the officer ahead of you on a limited-edition Nissan Skyline just dropped on you. This is an arcade - treat it like as it is, please. It's Need for Speed.

Want my final advice? Buy it. It's still a 2010 game, but still pretty much fun.

I think I bought this for under 5$ so I do not feel ripped off.

The sound track is pretty lame compared to similar titles, but I suppose you can turn it off and play your own music in another program.

It's too bad they didn't make this game more like GTA V or Burnout: Paradise where you could do things in the world besides race past them. But for a few dollars it isn't a bad relaxing drive through coasts, mountans, deserts, and urban areas.

reviewText:
I personally always had a fondness for racing games going back to the times of the first need for speed hot pursuit which i  quite liked and i find this this game to live up to it and in some aspects surpass it. The graphics in this game are great with beautiful landscapes ranging from snowy mountaintops to barren deserts and even a coastline. these great graphics include the  many diverse cars available throughout the game and for me the ability to play both the racer and cop sides adds intrigue to the game. Despite it having autolog and an apparent partial focus on multiplayer i rarely ever use such features but maybe thats just me.

Some of the things i most enjoyed about ithe game (pros) is the diversity of amazing cars, playing both cop and racer sides, stunning landscaps and the free roam mode plus drifting is awesome.

There are some things i didnt like including a lack of customization options for cars which i like to see on nfs games, lack of free roam related missions or objectives and a few slightly boring race modes.

All in all this game's diversity of style of play, great graphics and freedom in play make for a classic and fun racing game that can be played for hours.

reviewText:
This game is really a lot of fun.

I've been a fan of the old Hot Pursuit games and this is a really decent addition to the series.

If you liked those games you will like this one as well, it pretty much sticks to the original format, there are races where you're a street racer, and others where you play as a cop.

Only major difference is that you can charge up your nitrous through various actions on track, much like Need for Speed Underground 2, and this is necessary, since it helps you out a lot.

You also have kind of a level-up system, one for the racer part and one for the cop part.
Each race you're arwarded medals, which give you bounty (basically experience) which level you up and unlock cars and other stuff.

You have your gadgets like spike trips and others (need to unlock them though I think) to stop cars much like the old games.

Other than regular races, where you have to escape from cops / bust racers, there are also some times trials, which might seem boring to some people, but I personally enjoy this kind of challenge.

I found it a bit hard to get used to the controls though, braking and drifting just right is a bit hard with my wheel.

The only real letdown for me - There's no manual transmission. Why? Some people say the game is to hectic, especially during chases with racers/cops, but that is something I absolutely want in any racing game.

reviewText:
(I mostly play on Origin, so few hours on Steam here.)

It's Mario Kart with modern (for 2010) cars. No kidding. You're gonna cuss out your friends as they blast you with EMP (red shells), drop spike strips (triple banana!) and ram your pride and joy into oblivion on pristine Californian roads, be it in a stand-up race or a glorious battle to the death between corrupt cop and wealthy crook.

It's a very un-EA like game in some respects. By that I mean Hot Pursuit still has an awful online interface, but it's basically a complete game without DLC and fun offline, too. It has a solid campaign which should at least last a week of sporadic play. It's very very pretty and low intensity and will run on virtually any modern rig.

Sadly there's no customization and undercover gameplay. It's terribly unrealistic in terms of handling, vehicle dynamics and speed. Despite that, it's a far better competitive racing game than most of the NFS titles that came after it and offers a lot more refined value for your dollar. It's mostly glitch-free, absolutely gorgeous and a ton of fun to pick up at any time. Also it's absolutely infuriating.

You know the game spams visual cues every time your friends beat your lap times? ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• it.

reviewText:
I picked this game up after playing Underground 2, Most Wanted and Carbon for PS2 and, well, it's very different. It lacks the immersive tuning of the games I mentioned, has no real freedrive (there is one, but there's almost nothing to discover on the map - not even cop chases will occur) and isn't set in an urban surrounding but much more on highways and country roads.

After some time playing Hot Pursuit however I really started to like it. The races are much more challenging than any other NFS game I played, the different race modes can be amazing (the Hot Pursuit mode is so damn great!) and the range of cars available to unlock is immense. I personally wasn't so hyped about the Cop Mode and played it very little.

In the end, this game has not the underground racing, streetwise feeling Underground, Most Wanted and Carbon had but makes a really good effort in creating a scene where you focus on pure driving skills. A little Pro/Con list to sum it up.

PRO:
- graphics are very nice (note the release date, I know there are much better graphics on the market at the moment)
- great range of cars
- challenging
- awesome Hot Pursuit game mode
- no money grinding required for new cars/tuning equip
- SpeedWall comparing your time with those of friends keeps some competition between you and your mates

CON:
- no tuning at all
- cutscenes IN races can sometimes distract you which can be really saddening some times
- online is dead
- boring freeroam

Recommended for people wanting to focus on driving skills rather than creating a personalized racemashine and showing it off in urban environment.

reviewText:
A perfect makeover of the original except for the whole EA Autolog online BS.  Graphics are good, car control is predictable and the maps are gorgeous.  The only thing that brings this game down is the autolog.

It's not Forza or even Grid for that matter.  It's more of an arcade driving experience with a hint of simulation thrown in just to make it exciting.  This was the game that made Atari's Test Drive Unlimited look so awful.

Playing online or with friends is made somewhat cumbersome with the Autolog interface but it's far easier than Grid 2's Racenet so there's some redemption there.

Don't buy this game to stat boost your rank on some leaderboard.  Rather buy it because you remember Need for speed 3 ( the original version of this game) and wanted an updated and more visually experience with a wider array of tracks.

reviewText:
If you can get past the car manufacturer's corporate marketing and EA's insufferable obsession with forcing players into online communities and punishing lone wolves for not wanting or not being able to be continually connected, this is a fast, fun, gorgeous-looking arcade-style crash-em-up/time trial game.

Regardless of whether you're connected to an EA account, you can't skip the annoying 'Autolog' (the fancy name for the game's ever-present online connectivity feature) tutorial at the start, or stop the game from continually trying to connect to Autolog throughout play, even if it has registered a dozen times that it can't connect. And if you dare try to play an offline campaign, the game will force you to sit and read an advertisment for the feature before it will let you play. I'm not even sure if Autolog is supported any more, but it's as if the game itself is an ad for this feature, rather than the feature supporting the game. See that symbol on the game's picture? That's the Autolog symbol. What the hell.

In saying this, apart from being an annoyance, a lack of connectivity doesn't affect the gameplay itself. And the game is fun, if unforgiving at times. You can quite easily be eliminated within seconds of starting a race if you're not careful, however, the AI does allow you to catch up if you crash, and most of the cars handle very similarly, which is less realistic, but easier to pick up and play.

Although there are many cool and gorgeous cars to race, there aren't many modes to be seen in the campaign - I've played 4 hours of the police campaign and all you can do is a Time Trial, 'Interceptor' (in which you chase down a single car), and Hot Pursuit (in which you chase down a whole bunch of cars). Chasing down crims is never tedious, and watching them roll through the air when you finally take them out is always satisfying.

If you can get this cheap, then it's well worth your time. It's just a shame that no matter how far back you go in the last 10 years, EA shows signs of trying to impliment consistently ineffective and insidious online features into their games, with little concern for the integrity of the title. If the game didn't play so well I'd accuse it of being nothing more than an ad for its community features.

reviewText:
A perfect makeover of the original except for the whole EA Autolog online BS.  Graphics are good, car control is predictable and the maps are gorgeous.  The only thing that brings this game down is the autolog.

It's not Forza or even Grid for that matter.  It's more of an arcade driving experience with a hint of simulation thrown in just to make it exciting.  This was the game that made Atari's Test Drive Unlimited look so awful.

Playing online or with friends is made somewhat cumbersome with the Autolog interface but it's far easier than Grid 2's Racenet so there's some redemption there.

Don't buy this game to stat boost your rank on some leaderboard.  Rather buy it because you remember Need for speed 3 ( the original version of this game) and wanted an updated and more visually experience with a wider array of tracks.

reviewText:
Not the best Need For Speed game out there, there are a lot of cons in this one, in a short review, I recommend you to buy the NFS: Undercover, instead of this one or the NFS: Shift.

- The game has a possibility to play as a cop or a racer, but there are not that many cars and they arent able to be customized the way we want, we can only change their colors, and some of them have only one.
- The game difficulty is absurd, every new player will strugle a lot to get used to the game and proceed to the next levels, there should be a way of choosing the difficulty instead of being this hard game with no possibility to change that.
- The controls are also very weird, and there is no tutorial, which it should have since this game is really hard to play.

I've talked about the main negative parts of this game, now lets pass to the good parts.

- The graphics, they are beautifull in every way, the cars, the landscapes, every graphic on this game is stunning.
- This game soundtrack is the most accurate for a game like this, playing a cool music, with a fast car at night is a great experience, and something I would recommend you do if you have the game.

Well, should you buy this game? If you have no racing games or if you are a fan of the Need For Speed series like me you should, but if you never played any game from the series then try to play other ones first.

reviewText:
review of the campaign only:

you pick a race track, then you pick a car, then pick the color, and you race!
looks great!
there are no customization options in this game, every car is as powerful as it will ever be right off the bat.
loads of different cars to choice from though.
play as both the racer and the police trying to bust racers. you might think, why would i want to play as the police? well it is surprisingly fun! give it a try. you can do both the police and the racer campaign on the same save.
multiple race types on every track that unlock during the campaign.
you can turn off the online features and still do the campaign.
no race is stupidly easy, and none are impossible.

time trails, try and make crash 1 or more racers, regular race with or without cops, special skills like EMPs, and naturally lots of different cars make this game fun with a lot of variety (for a racing game ofc)

most annoying feature:
cutscenes at the start of every race, prevent you from jumping right into the action. you can not skip these completely. this is especially frustrating during the time trails.

spoiler free tip:
learn to pick the right kind of brake (hand or regular) as soon as possible, some time trails can not be done unless you have a basic mastery of this mechanic.

bottom line:
enjoy racing games, but don't like the (mandatory) customization or limitations (eg having to buy a car/parts before being able use them)? then this game is something for you! the 20 euro price might be a bit much, but if you buy it during a sale you will not be disappointed! (bought my copy for 5 euro recently)
also did i mention the DRM can be turned off so you are stuck with just steam? big plus right there, for all the people who do not want EA snooping around.

max settings work on my laptop: 8GB ram, 3GB nvidia g-ram, 3.3ghz, windows 7
other hardware: plays very well with a xbox 360 controller (i use a corded one)

reviewText:
Need For Speed III: Hot Pursuit was one on my favorite games back in the old Need For Speed days.

When they announced the revive of the Hot Pursuit series back in 2010, I was pretty excited. Driving in a high speed chase from the cops was a fun experince to have. Having to be the cop was a great experince to have if you want to be with the law and wrecking racers. There's a big list of cars ranging from everyday cars to one the most exotic and expensive cars in the world. They all have their unique characteristics of thier driving in Seacrest County. From the bulky Dodge Charger SRT8 to the lightweight Koeningsegg CCXR Edition. The county of Seacrest is a beautiful resemblance of four different enviroments mashed together with one of the most exhilerating roads I've seen in a modern Need For Speed game. The sounds in this game is mindbolowing. Where my head just couldn't handle it and I had to stop and catch myself before I pass out. Ok I'm kidding on that but really the vehicle sounds is really amazing.

Graphics
For a 2010 game, I have to say that this game itself is a pleasuring beauty. All enviroments ranging from the mountains to the desert have a beautiful scenery that keeps the driver in awe while driving in a intense race. The details of each vehicle is really amazing with high tessellation that helps the vehicle look more realistic and more immersive to drive. The carbon fiber on the Koenigsegg CCXR for example is just amazing. The lighting effects is just beautiful from day to night. The weather effects has got to be the best I've seen so far in a Need For Speed game. Seeing the relfection on the wet surface is really fantastic. The textures of the road is just amazing with each road having their own unique style to it. Also since this game is made by Criterion games. It's not surprising that the damage model is just jawdroping from every crash that you witness. The only complaint I do have to say is that theirs no Anti-Aliasing to be found in the game.

Gameplay
Since this game is supposed to bring back the original Hot Pursuit feel, there's obviously not going to be any customization. Which some people would complain but since all of this was based before Underground 1 and 2 it would make sense. Color picking has been reduced to manufatured paint only which is a bit disapointing. For the driving part, it's pretty fun driving every vehicle since they do have their own unique handling and drifting. What I thought was pretty interesting that the devopers added weight to the driving which makes it more realistic. For instance the Bentley Continental Coupe is a pretty heavy vehicle. It's pretty difficult to swerve the vehicle from left to right since it's a heavy car. For the Pangani Zonda Cinque, it's nimble so the car can swerve easily around traffic and the cops. This new pursuit weapon that Criterion Games added is a pretty cool feature. Each side (racer/cop) has some unique features that only one side can use (For instance cops can call in road blocks or a helicoptor whereas the racer can use either a jammer or turbo). In my opinion they'll seem to be balanced in a nice mannor. Freedrive is a decent experince since the player can use freedrive to test drive the car without having to deal with cops/racer or crashing out. The main downside is that since there's no option for a online freedrive, the replayability of that mode is small. This new social feature, Autolog, is a really nice feature that let's the player challenge their freinds, share photos and disscus. The downside to this is that people that has little to no friends will think that this feature is useless to them, but it's a not a flaw by any means. DLC wise..... well there's no DLC here becuase we know that EA doesn't like PC players that much besides Battlefield.

Conclusion
This game is a great succesor to the past Hot Pursuit games and I feel like this game is great for any casual or competitive players.

reviewText:
Picked this up for 5 euro's which is about as much i would pay for this game.

Goal:
So, the goal of the game seems to be to reach the highest ranking as either or both the racer and the cop, unlocking new cars in the progress. You will achieve both by doing races, including a variety of new cars which you then can race with. Well.. which you can sometimes race with I must say, because for some reason the game has its own preferences for cars and in some races you are just left with 1 pick (while the game shows you more unlocked cars, which you can't pick for some reason).

Then, there is no customization (sigh). A really big letdown for me, since this was what made the game series unique and was the biggest part of the reward system. This was what kept you playing, unlocking a new car, using your money to put some spoilers, wheels, neon lights etc. on it to make it your personal driving monster. Not being able to do this also made it less rewarding to unlock new cars like the camaro, which is one of my favorite cars.

So what about the leveling system, or the ranking system if you will.. well.. you unlock new cars and some new abilities (which you can only use for specific races), but thats pretty much it.. I felt no difference being a level 1 or a level 4 other than maybe difficulty.. Its just not rewarding enough anymore, since we all expect more.. If this game wasn't part of the nfs series, it would've been so much better.

Graphics:
The graphics look average at best. I guess there went more time in actually letting players drive cars then the actual looks, which saddens me if i look back into the series. Most of the nfs games had pretty damn good graphics for their time, especially for a racing game. This wouldn't have bothered me as much if it were only the landscape, it is also the car models. I've seen way better looking car models in the older nfs's and I don't expect a game series like nfs's size to go worse in graphics.

Ok.. so far for the bad stuff.. lets recap a sec: there is (in my opinion) no real goal in the game other than winning races and gaining rank. The rewards are race specific abilities and cars, which are less rewarding since you can't even customize them. The graphics are average at best, the cars being the biggest let down for me (graphics wise).

The driving:
So what is GOOD about the game, why should you buy it if you dissagree with the above? well..  the racing is pretty good, I love the drifting and the way nitro works in this game. It adds alot of tactic/strategy to the racing, which is cool. You can cut alot of turns or you can try and always get nitro back by driving against traffic, closely passing by cars and drifting (against traffic). Drifiting also is really important. You shouldn't always drift, and when drifting you get the choice of the optimal route or the route where you get the most nitro of.


Conclusion:
So its up to you. my advice: if you look for a nfs game, just stay with carbon, it had really nice driving, police chases were epic (throwing wood of trucs to cut them off etc.), customization was still in the game and the game had somewhat of a story/sense of progression. If you are just looking for a racing game, don't really care about customization or graphics, but just (unrealistic) racing. Then this is your game. And ofcourse.. if you have 5 bucks spare.. you can look yourself and see if you share my opinion ^^!

reviewText:
I'm not a huge racing game fan and so I'm not that nitpicky about graphics and cars and whatnot but one day, I decided that I felt like I should play a racing game. And so, I went on the internet and looked for the best racing games available out there and well, Need For Speed: Hot Pursuit was on the top of a lot of lists. I bought the game, played the game and well, I can honestly say that NFS:Hot Pursuit is probably the only racing game I'll ever need to have because, to put it simply, it has everything I've wanted in a racing game.

When it comes to graphics and presentation, this game is simply...gorgeous. From the details of the cars to the realistic looking environments and weather to the slick and stylistic design of the user interface, everything just looks polished and well-done. Not to mention that the crashes in this game look absolutely stunning. Someone could probably record a bunch of the crashes in this game, compile them into a screensaver and it would be one of the best looking screensavers ever made! The sound is mindblowingly immersive (just listening to your engine roar as you achieve 100+ KPH through your headphones really make you feel as if you're inside that car) and the controls are exceedingly responsive and intuitive. Not to mention, the gameplay is pretty forgiving for those like me who could be considered fairly 'noob' to the genre and it has that fairly 'Arcade' style for the more casual players but it can still be incredibly fun and challenging for veterans and racing game enthusiasts.

Need for Speed: Hot Pursuit is an incredibly well-made and well-polished game that's great for just about everyone and is the type of game that should be on everyone's steam library.

reviewText:
There's a Wow factor to this game that tops anyother racing game. -8/10

Personally, my favorite racing game of all time is Need for Speed MostWanted (Gamecube), funny enough this game is nothing like it. No open world to explore, no car customizations, no more cars that cost ingame money... nothing. But don't let this fool you. Criterion Games has built this to be a realisting, aracde like racing game. The gameplay is built to be fun and nothing else. The cars are free, so once they're unlocked go ahead and use them. The gamplay is easy to learn and is very balanced. The graphics are insane+car crashes are very amusing to watch. This is not what you'd expect from most NFS game but it might just be a whole lot better.

Moving on the small issues I have with the game. First off, I have already mentioned the differences to other racing titles, and yes there are a lot of differences, but I really like the change of flavor. So thats not really a problem. Secondly, the game gets repetitive. You learn it quickly and after that, there's nothing else to learn. It's just the same kind of races over and over  again over again (#definitionofinsanityfarcry3). The last problem I have with the game is the time trials. I hate them, understand this.... you have to do perfectly on the course, take all the shortcuts, don't crash once then maybe you will get gold (the amount of bounty you get to level up depends on the medal placement the game uses). Even then it might not happen. I've been off by 0.03 seconds from getting gold, even worse, I've lost gold by 0.01s. Just stay away from the time trials and you will have a great experience.

In the end it's your decision on whether you get this game or not, but I'm telling you this... if you buy this game, you will not regret it. Straight up, its fun. I recommend everyone to give this game a try. -8/10

reviewText:
Well, I've been playing the Career mode of the game for a couple of hours and thought I'd share my experience with this game.

My ExpectationsI've never actually played one of the Need For Speed games prior to this one. I used to play Burnout Legends on XBOX and was looking for a similar game on Steam. That's when I purchased this one, judging by the review it seemed the closest to Burnout Legends.

Career ModeRacing game's Career mode is what I'm after, so I was really looking forward to the one in Need For Speed. No surprise here, it's about climbing the ladder and become a Most Wanted (or the cop version of it, haven't played it much, though). During your career you'll drive faster cars, perform more risky stunts, take more (intelligent) shortcuts and try to keep your opponents behind you.

Very Hot PursuitThe game is very, very challenging. Very. If you think Burnout's Career mode is challenging, you've seen nothing yet. And I'm not talking about 80% through, I'm talking about 10-20%. This is both good and bad. With enough patience, you can improve your driving (and eventually beat the game). But it might just as well get you frustrated.

Proper Game Controller Support, Anyone?I used to think that driving games would be played best with a computer driving wheel controller, but that was actually more difficult than it was fun. Playing Burnout Legends using the XBOX controller was nice, so I was looking forward to a proper Game Controller Support. Unfortunately, Need For Speed fails to deliver. Although the controller is supported out-of-the-box the button mapping and the overall controller sensitivity feels to fragile. Seriously, when I play a car racing game that's about risky driving maneuvers I don't want the controls to be configured as if I had a think piece of glass in my hand that'd brake anytime soon. Admittedly, that's very subjective, but maybe there are others that are looking for the same thing that I was.

Cut The Videos, Please!In my career, all medals have to be gold. I don't know why, but I like to beat the score and finish the level, so to say. That's why I prefer cutscenes to be skip-able, restart the whole race quickly, load up a new level, etc. I've recently upgraded my setup and was expecting Need For Speed: Hot Pursuit to load and respond rather quickly. But the opposite is true: It takes f****ng ages to load, restart or quit a race. Seriously: Why does the game need to load (!) the whole map again when I just want to restart the race on the map that is already in memory?
Sorry, but this is one of the biggest annoyances with this game for me.

Speedwall? Forever Alone!After every race I'm presented with a Speedwall which I suppose is some kind of highscore. Only problem is: I'm the only one on that list. No one to compete with, not even strangers from the server. Only my score. Yes, I get it, the game is not the newest one available, and propably none of my friends even plays it. But then please let me challenges other players from around the globe and compare to some international ranking.

tl;dr: Summary+ Very challenging
+ Integrates with Big Picture
+ Native XBOX 360 USB Controller support
+ Nice graphics
+ Great, motivating soundtrack
+ Fun to play

- Very challenging
- XBOX 360 USB Controller configuration/sensitivity doesn't match a racing game
- Shortcuts can be well-hidden and often require a good knowledge of the map
- Autolog is annoying. Signing up for an account? - I'm logged in to Steam already!
- Online leaderboard doesn't work or is not available
- Incredible long (and unnecessary) loading processes, even for restarting only a race on that very same map. Seriously?

reviewText:
Need for Speed Hot Pursuit launches you into a new open-world landscape behind the wheel of the world's fastest and most beautiful cars. From Criterion, the award-winning studio behind the Burnout series, Hot Pursuit will redefine racing games for a whole new generation.

You'll experience stunning speeds, takedowns, and getaways as you battle your friends in the most connected Need for Speed game ever. Through Need for Speed Autolog and its innovative approach to connected social competition, your Hot Pursuit experience will extend beyond the console onto the web, constantly moving your gameplay in new and unique directions.

Loaded with action, this game will challenge you to become Seacrest County's top cop or most wanted racer. For the first time ever in a Need for Speed game, you'll be able to play a full career on either side of the law. Whether you're a lead-foot speeder or a cop with a mean streak, make sure your aviators are spotless and your driving record is anything but.

reviewText:
As a long time NFS Fan, and seeing the nonsense Critereon had done to my favorite racing franchise, I have to say... They actually did it right.

Now, this isn't a game that's traditional to the NFS Franchise, there's no open world, and of course, you can play as the cops as well, but to me, this game is a lot like Carbon without the open world, and more fast paced and suspenseful than Carbon could of even dreamed of.

~Pros
+Driving in this game seems a lot more suspenseful and genuinely fun than other NFS titles (not all, however)
+Drifting system in this game may not be realistic, but they absolutely nailed the drifting system for something arcade style.
+Vehicle selection is absolutely awesome, the roster might not be as big as other titles, but I find I can drive every single car and enjoy it.
+Multiplayer is absolutely -awesome-. there's much less lag than other NFS titles, and the Hot Pursuit mode is wicked fun.
+Easy to pick up, put down, or play consistently, casual and hardcore friendly.
+Keyboard support is phenomenal compared to other NFS titles, it doesn't feel like you NEED a wheel or controller.

~Cons
-No Open World
-Multiplayer community is lacking (as all racing games suffer.) (matchmaking can take a while.)
-Very limited graphics options (Is not old-pc friendly, but the awesome optimization from Dice allows for low-end PC's to run it fine at 30-60 fps with minimal frame drops)
-Occasional frame drops on low end systems.

~Toss-ups
*Arcade style racing, this is NOT a sim.
*Power-up style gameplay on some races, EMP's, Spike Strips, etc, this fits perfectly imo because of being able to play as police.
*Drifting System is not realistic, however, imo, this the first game to nail an arcade style drifting system, no other game competes.
*Cars auto-unlock in an order, all cars however remain driveable, there is no purchasing system, you get cars by getting reputation through driving and have access to all cars you have unlocked at all times.
*Solid change-up from the traditional NFS franchise, however, imo, it's a very well done change-up, and is definitely a fun title worthy of being deemed Need For Speed.

Imo, I absolutely love it, the frame drops can be tedious, but my system isn't very good, you may never get those, don't let my ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• system discourage you. I also dislike the lack of an open world, however, there's so much veriety in this game I cannot find myself to get bored with this title, it's just awesome and I'm striving to hit those gold medals on every race, the arcade drifting system is insanely well done, and while some people might think of it as NFS meets Mario Kart, they're far from right, this has got to be the most fun action/racing combo I've ever played, and it blows every Burnout title out of the water.

8.5/10

reviewText:
I've had this game for a week and I can already say that I am very impressed with what EA and Criterion Games have created. I've been hooked on NFS for about 4 years now, and I've played Most Wanted 2012 and World (Free MMO) since then. This game never ceases to amaze me with the graphics, the adrenaline, the challenging challenges, and the replay factor. It doesn't get boring and single player is always fun. I found that with Most Wanted 2012, as soon as I finished the game, there wasn't much else to do, and it got boring as the variety wasn't really there with the small map and lack of cop career. That is not the case with Hot Pursuit, and there is little to complain about in this game.

One thing that I did find to be irritating at times was that the AI was sometimes unfair. Sometimes as a cop I'd be playing a hot pursuit event, and one of the other racers would crash into a traffic car. It'd then respawn and accelerate insanely quickly and pass by me like a rocket. I found it to be unrealistic and unfair, but it didn't really affect my experience very much because the rest of the game was just so well made that my entertainment was not influenced at all.

I wish people would play multiplayer, but I don't really blame anyone seeing as this game is old now, and I should have picked it up earlier in my lifetime. Nevertheless, I can still proudly say that this purchase was worth it. So far, it is my favorite NFS game of the new generation (Criterion Editions) that I have played. I can't speak for Rivals, but I'm assuming the experience I would have playing it would be within the ballpark.

Final Verdict: 9/10

reviewText:
I don't have almost any other racing games other than this one. But I'm thankful this is the one I have.

Pros:
- The graphics are very good for being a few years old, and I hear it runs on lower end computers as well. Like, this game could've come out in 2014 and still be great.
- Driving feels solid and real. Taking close corners never felt better driving your favorite car. Might want a controller, but my brother uses a keyboard and does fine.
- Community? You can't talk ever. I met a Russian online and at the end of the race we just flashed our high-beams at each other. True bliss. 10/10 would race with him again.
- No DLC. No more cars. No feelings to fork more money for more stuff.
Cons:
- Music isn't the absolute best. I've heard better in NFS Carbon. But it's ok because you can just blast your own tunes in your favorite music player.
- The online feels kinda clunky sometimes, but once you understand it, it's ok. This is EA after all, the twerps that made Origin. Stop trying to be Steam. Just stop.
- There isn't the LARGEST selection of cars, but there are enough to drive each of them for a while. (I have over 700 miles in the Bugatti Veyron right now.) Also, you can't customize your car, which to me was kinda heartbreaking. The gamemakers said something about trying to make the cars look beautiful without customization. And they do look beautiful, but I would've liked customization.

In conclusion, the cons are very small, and the pros outshine the small problems. I've logged plenty of hours, and plan to put more into.
This is a good game to just boot up, blast some tunes, let out some fumes, drift some corners, and rev some engines.

reviewText:
Among the TOP Racing Games on Steam!

Initially, I purchased Need for Speed: Hot Persuit for Xbox 360. As I played the game on console, I realized that it had a great story line, but the graphics were a bit drab. So after about 2 days of having the game, I sold it back to GameStop, purchasing a Steam Card, for the Summer Sale. Without thinking any further, I purchased the game on Steam, as I knew I wasn't feeling the full effect without playing it on PC.

After playing the game for an hour or so on PC, I realized how high-detailed this game is, for it's time. Sure it's not the best game out there (comparing it to newer titles like Forza 5), but this game is indeed a graphical wonderland. The physics, the textures, the storyline, the price, are all a crucial factor when it comes to reviewing this game.

The graphics, like I previously mentioned, are definitely better than I had anticipated (even on console. Can you believe that?). The shadow effects, textures, reslolution, anti-aliasing, everything seemed to be rather well-produced, compared to other games of it's time (ie: Grand Theft Auto 4).

Story. I am not one who typically likes the storyline of Need For Speed titles, being they vary from title to title, but this one was one of the better ones. Rather than having to stick to a specific story, you have an option to merely choose your side; cops or crooks. Regardless which side you choose, it's a a ton of fun.

The online experience is pretty good as well. I love playing games online, but I was a bit of a skeptic when it came to playing this game online. But after playing a few rounds, I felt that it was pretty addicting, to be honest. Atleast it didn't make me ragequit like COD games.

Furthermore, the game was very well produced, weighing in at one of the top racing games, in my steam account. I have played a large amount of games between those on Xbox and on PC, and I would have to say this game is in the top 3.

Cons: I think car customization should be offered, as that is a necessity in having the perfect car. Game gets a bit repetitive after some time, of continually doing the same runs. Online community is a bit dried up, compared to other online games. I would like to see some improvements made to this game for the full 100. For now, I would have to say: 85/100

reviewText:
Among the TOP Racing Games on Steam!

Initially, I purchased Need for Speed: Hot Persuit for Xbox 360. As I played the game on console, I realized that it had a great story line, but the graphics were a bit drab. So after about 2 days of having the game, I sold it back to GameStop, purchasing a Steam Card, for the Summer Sale. Without thinking any further, I purchased the game on Steam, as I knew I wasn't feeling the full effect without playing it on PC.

After playing the game for an hour or so on PC, I realized how high-detailed this game is, for it's time. Sure it's not the best game out there (comparing it to newer titles like Forza 5), but this game is indeed a graphical wonderland. The physics, the textures, the storyline, the price, are all a crucial factor when it comes to reviewing this game.

The graphics, like I previously mentioned, are definitely better than I had anticipated (even on console. Can you believe that?). The shadow effects, textures, reslolution, anti-aliasing, everything seemed to be rather well-produced, compared to other games of it's time (ie: Grand Theft Auto 4).

Story. I am not one who typically likes the storyline of Need For Speed titles, being they vary from title to title, but this one was one of the better ones. Rather than having to stick to a specific story, you have an option to merely choose your side; cops or crooks. Regardless which side you choose, it's a a ton of fun.

The online experience is pretty good as well. I love playing games online, but I was a bit of a skeptic when it came to playing this game online. But after playing a few rounds, I felt that it was pretty addicting, to be honest. Atleast it didn't make me ragequit like COD games.

Furthermore, the game was very well produced, weighing in at one of the top racing games, in my steam account. I have played a large amount of games between those on Xbox and on PC, and I would have to say this game is in the top 3.

Cons: I think car customization should be offered, as that is a necessity in having the perfect car. Game gets a bit repetitive after some time, of continually doing the same runs. Online community is a bit dried up, compared to other online games. I would like to see some improvements made to this game for the full 100. For now, I would have to say: 85/100

reviewText:
I recommend this game whole heartedly.  The graphics are decent by today's standards.  As a 2010 game. that's pretty impressive.  They are good enough to be immersive and give you the feel of racing.

Any decent system by today's standards can run it fully maxed no problem.  Unfortunately, it does not have AA option,but there are mods that offer that, at least for Nvidia cards.

The action is good. It's an arcade game, and as a GAME, it shines.  It is not a sim, it is not realistic, and that is not the goal.

I haven't used online at all.  The career mode is a lot of fun, both as racer and as cop and you can switch back and forth.

There are a lot of racing slobs.  it's a genre that invites that sort, and I am sure there are plenty who slag on this game and others of its ilk incessantly.

It's great fun.  Period.

I've played 4 different NFS games and this is as fun as any of them.

It is absolutely worth $5.  No question about it

reviewText:
I'm not a huge racing game fan and so I'm not that nitpicky about graphics and cars and whatnot but one day, I decided that I felt like I should play a racing game. And so, I went on the internet and looked for the best racing games available out there and well, Need For Speed: Hot Pursuit was on the top of a lot of lists. I bought the game, played the game and well, I can honestly say that NFS:Hot Pursuit is probably the only racing game I'll ever need to have because, to put it simply, it has everything I've wanted in a racing game.

When it comes to graphics and presentation, this game is simply...gorgeous. From the details of the cars to the realistic looking environments and weather to the slick and stylistic design of the user interface, everything just looks polished and well-done. Not to mention that the crashes in this game look absolutely stunning. Someone could probably record a bunch of the crashes in this game, compile them into a screensaver and it would be one of the best looking screensavers ever made! The sound is mindblowingly immersive (just listening to your engine roar as you achieve 100+ KPH through your headphones really make you feel as if you're inside that car) and the controls are exceedingly responsive and intuitive. Not to mention, the gameplay is pretty forgiving for those like me who could be considered fairly 'noob' to the genre and it has that fairly 'Arcade' style for the more casual players but it can still be incredibly fun and challenging for veterans and racing game enthusiasts.

Need for Speed: Hot Pursuit is an incredibly well-made and well-polished game that's great for just about everyone and is the type of game that should be on everyone's steam library.

reviewText:
Well, I've been playing the Career mode of the game for a couple of hours and thought I'd share my experience with this game.

My ExpectationsI've never actually played one of the Need For Speed games prior to this one. I used to play Burnout Legends on XBOX and was looking for a similar game on Steam. That's when I purchased this one, judging by the review it seemed the closest to Burnout Legends.

Career ModeRacing game's Career mode is what I'm after, so I was really looking forward to the one in Need For Speed. No surprise here, it's about climbing the ladder and become a Most Wanted (or the cop version of it, haven't played it much, though). During your career you'll drive faster cars, perform more risky stunts, take more (intelligent) shortcuts and try to keep your opponents behind you.

Very Hot PursuitThe game is very, very challenging. Very. If you think Burnout's Career mode is challenging, you've seen nothing yet. And I'm not talking about 80% through, I'm talking about 10-20%. This is both good and bad. With enough patience, you can improve your driving (and eventually beat the game). But it might just as well get you frustrated.

Proper Game Controller Support, Anyone?I used to think that driving games would be played best with a computer driving wheel controller, but that was actually more difficult than it was fun. Playing Burnout Legends using the XBOX controller was nice, so I was looking forward to a proper Game Controller Support. Unfortunately, Need For Speed fails to deliver. Although the controller is supported out-of-the-box the button mapping and the overall controller sensitivity feels to fragile. Seriously, when I play a car racing game that's about risky driving maneuvers I don't want the controls to be configured as if I had a think piece of glass in my hand that'd brake anytime soon. Admittedly, that's very subjective, but maybe there are others that are looking for the same thing that I was.

Cut The Videos, Please!In my career, all medals have to be gold. I don't know why, but I like to beat the score and finish the level, so to say. That's why I prefer cutscenes to be skip-able, restart the whole race quickly, load up a new level, etc. I've recently upgraded my setup and was expecting Need For Speed: Hot Pursuit to load and respond rather quickly. But the opposite is true: It takes f****ng ages to load, restart or quit a race. Seriously: Why does the game need to load (!) the whole map again when I just want to restart the race on the map that is already in memory?
Sorry, but this is one of the biggest annoyances with this game for me.

Speedwall? Forever Alone!After every race I'm presented with a Speedwall which I suppose is some kind of highscore. Only problem is: I'm the only one on that list. No one to compete with, not even strangers from the server. Only my score. Yes, I get it, the game is not the newest one available, and propably none of my friends even plays it. But then please let me challenges other players from around the globe and compare to some international ranking.

tl;dr: Summary+ Very challenging
+ Integrates with Big Picture
+ Native XBOX 360 USB Controller support
+ Nice graphics
+ Great, motivating soundtrack
+ Fun to play

- Very challenging
- XBOX 360 USB Controller configuration/sensitivity doesn't match a racing game
- Shortcuts can be well-hidden and often require a good knowledge of the map
- Autolog is annoying. Signing up for an account? - I'm logged in to Steam already!
- Online leaderboard doesn't work or is not available
- Incredible long (and unnecessary) loading processes, even for restarting only a race on that very same map. Seriously?

reviewText:
There's a Wow factor to this game that tops anyother racing game. -8/10

Personally, my favorite racing game of all time is Need for Speed MostWanted (Gamecube), funny enough this game is nothing like it. No open world to explore, no car customizations, no more cars that cost ingame money... nothing. But don't let this fool you. Criterion Games has built this to be a realisting, aracde like racing game. The gameplay is built to be fun and nothing else. The cars are free, so once they're unlocked go ahead and use them. The gamplay is easy to learn and is very balanced. The graphics are insane+car crashes are very amusing to watch. This is not what you'd expect from most NFS game but it might just be a whole lot better.

Moving on the small issues I have with the game. First off, I have already mentioned the differences to other racing titles, and yes there are a lot of differences, but I really like the change of flavor. So thats not really a problem. Secondly, the game gets repetitive. You learn it quickly and after that, there's nothing else to learn. It's just the same kind of races over and over  again over again (#definitionofinsanityfarcry3). The last problem I have with the game is the time trials. I hate them, understand this.... you have to do perfectly on the course, take all the shortcuts, don't crash once then maybe you will get gold (the amount of bounty you get to level up depends on the medal placement the game uses). Even then it might not happen. I've been off by 0.03 seconds from getting gold, even worse, I've lost gold by 0.01s. Just stay away from the time trials and you will have a great experience.

In the end it's your decision on whether you get this game or not, but I'm telling you this... if you buy this game, you will not regret it. Straight up, its fun. I recommend everyone to give this game a try. -8/10

reviewText:
I don't have almost any other racing games other than this one. But I'm thankful this is the one I have.

Pros:
- The graphics are very good for being a few years old, and I hear it runs on lower end computers as well. Like, this game could've come out in 2014 and still be great.
- Driving feels solid and real. Taking close corners never felt better driving your favorite car. Might want a controller, but my brother uses a keyboard and does fine.
- Community? You can't talk ever. I met a Russian online and at the end of the race we just flashed our high-beams at each other. True bliss. 10/10 would race with him again.
- No DLC. No more cars. No feelings to fork more money for more stuff.
Cons:
- Music isn't the absolute best. I've heard better in NFS Carbon. But it's ok because you can just blast your own tunes in your favorite music player.
- The online feels kinda clunky sometimes, but once you understand it, it's ok. This is EA after all, the twerps that made Origin. Stop trying to be Steam. Just stop.
- There isn't the LARGEST selection of cars, but there are enough to drive each of them for a while. (I have over 700 miles in the Bugatti Veyron right now.) Also, you can't customize your car, which to me was kinda heartbreaking. The gamemakers said something about trying to make the cars look beautiful without customization. And they do look beautiful, but I would've liked customization.

In conclusion, the cons are very small, and the pros outshine the small problems. I've logged plenty of hours, and plan to put more into.
This is a good game to just boot up, blast some tunes, let out some fumes, drift some corners, and rev some engines.

reviewText:
This IS a good racing game if you like mostly arcadey controls, but it seems like people think this is vastly different game from the other 'arcadey' NFS games, it isn't.   Other than the Shift series, they all have same open world feel/layout/etc

I see a number of reviews stating that this is 'the best NFS game', to which I strongly disagree.

The first NFS Shift game was and still is one of the best as far as the driving/racing experience is concerned.  Granted, it doesn't have missions, open world, rivals, cops/racers, etc, but it IS a 'Need For Speed' game, and I think if they could blend the upgrade system and driving experience from Shift with the open world and polished feel of the Most Wanted, it WOULD be the best.

reviewText:
I really like this NFS game. Is it one of the best?.....no. Is it one of the worst?........no.

Positives:
It has great graphics and the recycled NFS controls which make it very enjoyable.
The racing style is a remake of the original Hot Pursuit (obviously).
The racing is great and being the cop is what made the original game so popular.

Negatives:
When compared to games like Most Wanted and Carbon, it does not have any traces of a story line or story behind your character and the surrounding area.
It does not have a free roam that includes chases. The only thing this free roam has is traffic, all you do is drive around and learn the roads. It eventually gets boring once done with the arcade style Career" mode.

Graphics: 9/10
Controls: 10/10
"Story": 6/10 [if it can be called that?]
Racing: 8/10
Overall: 7/10

(While not as good as its more recent counterparts; HP makes up for it with great controls and graphics.)

reviewText:
This is hands down one of the best arcade racers I've played, but it's not without its faults. Let's begin with the down sides to the game:
-The Ai is too clingy and elastic, it will shoot right back at you.
-The stats of the cars don't matter. No matter if the have the fastest Lambo, a slower Aston will always beat you.
-Events can begin to repeate and get boring
-There's no satisfaction, only hatred after a race.
-Music is hands down the worst I've heard in a game.
-It's too linear, weapons are restrictive to certain events
- The game forces you to choose from a seclection from only two cars during some events
- Unlocks seem pointless, due to the fact that you can't drive these cars until 10 races later, but by then you will have unclocked a faster set of cars.
- Game punishes you by not connecting to autolog
Now onto the plus sides of the game:
+ The games is very pretty, both at night and during the day.
+ The cars are very individual and throaty
+ The handling of the cars are very nice to control
+ Scenery is beautiful
+ Cops are a nice tocuh to the game.
+ Cars seems throaty and heavy.
+ The free drive is very relaxing and gives you practice on the tracks.
All in all, I'm going to give this game a 7.9/10
If the game was less restrictive and linear, I would give it a 8 or even a 9. At the time of rating, the game has decided to delete my game save file, and as a conclusion, I have gathered a complete save file from online and has taken all progression from the game. I would recommed this game, but only slightly. The faults can be overlooked, but can get to you after a while.

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Beautiful graphics
+ A good variety of races
+ Fluent controls
+ Overall it's just a lot of fun
+ Child proof - you will get to finish a race even if you only hold down the 'forward' button AND you can start races
just by pressing 'Enter' several times

Cons:
- The 'Interceptor' missions relied on luck on a lot of occasions not purely on the player's racing skills which meant that you had to replay those missions until the 'luck' occurred.
- 'Skip intro' means SKIP INTRO not 'Skip part of the intro' or 'Skip half of the intro'.
- Due to the game's simple nature it was also extremely linear.

Verdict:
It's an addictive racing game with very good replay value. Definitely amongst the best games I've played.

reviewText:
Time to redo this review and keep it short. Need for Speed Hot Pursuit graphics are beautiful. Now that I got that out of the way lets go into what the developers did wrong in this game that misses the mark for me, a long time hard-core Need for Speed fan that's been there since game one.
Unforgivable #1 - They dropped the gear shift. Need for Speed was never an easy game to master but once they dropped the gear shift it became impossible for me. Anyways I've always loved the thrill of shifting gears and waiting for the rpm's to hit that sweet spot. It's was also an excellent way to control your speed on sections of the race track where excess speed gets you into trouble.
Unforgivable #2 - Poorly defined short-cuts and short-cuts that in reality are long-cuts. Nothing frustrating like seeing a short-cut then need inhuman reflexes to use it even when you even know exactly where it is and long-cuts are just cheap when it's hard just to get on. Even then the short-cuts are hard to tell where to turn on them and you find yourself smacking into the wall going 'which way do I turn, which way do I turn?' to yourself.
Unforgivable #3 - Exceedingly long loading time for each race compounded on the fact that even on restarts you get the same exceedingly long load. You know what? I don't mind the first long load, I'll wait for it but if I'm restarting a race because of a minor mistake racing and I'm going for gold, waiting another two minutes for it to reload is madding. The track and race are already in memory, why torture me with the reload? Especially if I'm trying to get around a difficult spot with it fresh in my mind?
Need for Speed I-III on the Playstation never tortured me with these unforgivables. Those versions were hard too but this newest version upgrades and all just drive me nuts. Some days I love this game but most I hate it but because I'm a Need for Speed freak I just don't have the heart to un-install it. Maybe this is a good game for others who haven't played the Playstation versions and don't know what they are missing and learned bad habbits from the first three but as a hard-core Need for Speed fan I still can't recommend this game because I know where the orignal magic came from and it's not in this one.

The gameplay itself is good, BUT:

Buy this game if you can accept these things.

reviewText:
NFS:HP is a re-make of a rather bland entry into the NFS collection.  It's likely superior to its predecessor, but still has some glaring flaws.

This game has the worst rubber-band AI in the industry.  It's entirely on-rails, and holds no car customization beyond paint color.  When you do get to branch out a bit, getting multiple missions at the same time, they are still quite limited in their scope.  Unlocking new cars is nearly always just a method to go back to old races and set better times.

I don't recommend this game.  If you want a good NFS game with modern graphics, wait, or play Most Wanted.

i thought this was going to be a blast like the old NFSMW. boy was i wrong.
first, you have to get through the whole voice over monologue explaining all the features the game has, like taking screenines and posting them to your EA wall. just what i want. a none-facebook facebook, but only for people i know who play this game.
no way you can skip this, or helpfully only get instructions based on what you've selected. no. you have to suffer every grinding minute - yes minutes, get a stop watch and time it, of gormless yada yadaa yada nonesense.
now. once you got through that, oh what a minute, you want to race? ok, lets do this you think. ah, but no.
you will spend more time listening to the fake woman radio operator telling you about this is a car, this is how a car works, this is what a car looks like... again, unskippable, than you will actually driving - seriously. the police introduction chase is only about 30 seconds worth. hit bad guys car twice, and woo well done, welcome to the next bit of unskippable monolouge. the monoluge wouldn't be a problem if it was
