reviewText:
Need for speed - Sellout Edition maybe.  Once upon a time NFS involved a bit of acrade-style racing that was fun.  These cars handle more like hovercraft:  If you see it, you WILL hit it.  They decided to add the popular 'it takes time to turn your steering wheel' mechanic, which, let's face it:  Is completely bonkers for a decent racing game.
I only played the police side of it, so maybe the actual 'racing' part is better, but...  I doubt it.  The physics just don't seem to support the ability to actually turn without 'drifing'.  Even at speeds greater than 150 in cars that are built to add down-force, the game designers seemed to think that drifting will still make you turn better.

In other words, the game tries too hard to be 'realistic' with it's steering/physics system while ignoring the effects of downforce on cornering, to the point that it becomes pointless to play.  Then they added a drifting mechanic to try to make up for it, which is completely unrealistic.

reviewText:
Well, we were searching for a game to play together and we stumbled over this fun little racing game. I said little because that's the truth here, there is so little to do, almost nothing. I feel like the only thing to do is playing multiplayer races. If you consider buying this, only do so if it is ON SALE. I'm giving this game a downvote because you should not have to pay money for a game this thin and dissappointing.

Pros:

-The multiplayer. You only have very few mods though, and after two days of playing you know every single racing track (like, every single one of them)
-The graphics. Definitely not top-notch but it fits the game and the lighting effects are really cool and seem realistic.
-The sounds. Nothing out of the ordinary here, the music tracks are a matter of taste. The intro is way too loud though.
-The driving. It feels nice and responsive, nothing bad about it.

Cons:

-The singleplayer. I don't think EA was sober when they made this. Its an insult.
-Stuff besides the racing. No tuning, you may only choose from some colours to spray your car in.
-The tracks. Repetitive, but not always lame, cool shortcuts but overall not enough diversity.
-(The multiplayer. As I said, its fun, but you've got so few modes that it gets boring pretty quick.)

Conclusion:

This game could have been so much more. Its a dissappointment. If you want to play a better multiplayer racing game from the NFS series, try the new Most Wanted (Singleplayer sucks here, though). The multiplayer has a whole city, cool modes and is just way more interactive when playing with friends. So, don't buy Hot Pursuit, better get Most Wanted or something else because this here is not what I would call a good game.

reviewText:
This was one of the first modern racing games I played. I hadn't played a racing game in quite a while beforehand.
.. and I was disappointed. I remember playing Hot Pursuit 2 in the past on the Gamecube? or some console around that time and it was pretty cool.. it had good visuals for its time, an awesome soundtrack, fun levels, and a great car selection complete with the ability to freely set up tracks and play as you want alone or with friends. That was a cool game.

This one isn't.

Visually it looks good. The music is.. meh. The music is boring. The title or level select screens don't have that awesome upbeat style the older Hot Pursuit games did. Its so dark and boring.

The actual levels have a limited selection of vehicles of choice. The sense of speed is pretty good, but the levels are very very basic. Despite being a more arcadey game, it kind of felt like you should just play a racing simulator instead.
Its like, a weird in-between of arcadey awesome and simulation and fails to deliver on either.
There are some more arcadey game modes where you drop spike traps and things like that and they're just boring. Being chased by cops is dull.

The whole game is incredibly bland. Oh, and there isn't even a free-play mode where you choose a level and any car you
want + other settings like cops on or off, difficulty, and a bunch of other things the old NFS games had.
Yeah, that doesn't exist at all. There's multiplayer but I never tried it. All you get is a singleplayer campaign with no story and limitations.

Maybe I didn't give it enough of a chance but I found myself tired of it too early on to keep playing.
This game just isn't very good and there are much better racing games out there.

reviewText:
It's a fun, well coded game that offers challenge to fit anyone, provided they are good enough at racing.  You may find this game too difficult at times, though not so if you are 'perfect' and never crash (due to the scripted opponents).  The sounds are pretty good (definately OK here), and the music is 'just ok' - unless you're a kid these days, it most likely won't appeal too much to you (there is a song by Black Rebel Motorcycle Band in here though so take what I say with a grain of salt).  Shut the music off an leave your own playlist on Winamp or media player for windows if it bothers you - easy enough fix.  Opponents are scripted to give constant challenge.  There is no 'easy' 'medium' or 'hard' settings - with which brings me my biggest issue.  I *LOVED* playing need for speed III hot pursuit on my old pentium 2/3 computers back in the end of the 90s when I was underage in High School, and I bought this game on sale (so I can't complain that much) to see if it had the same flair.  This game will definately fit the bill if you like racing games, but I Implore to you as a potential customer that it IS NOT the same game.  I don't know what's happened to EA over the last few years, but they don't make the same games they used to.  Seems like the last 10 years, they have been changing the way opponents are scripted to 'race' with you, so that to always provide challenge, they always 'keep up'.  This RUINS the feeling of accomplishment, entirely.  If they're always right behind, you'd think that'd keep me on my toes, NO, that just keeps me crashing :x   This is not the GAMES fault, it's the fault of the human mind (that's also why police chases work, and this is HOT PURSUIT so this could have entirely been planned).  I am not just talking about police chases.  I still recommend this game entirely, wholeheartedly.  Just keep in mind when you buy this that the opponenets will go a set speed when ahead of you, and boost like crazy to keep up to you.  Top Gear 1 and 2 for the SNES *DID THE SAME THING* I am not kidding one bit - and we all loved those games (if we were old enough, I was a pre-teen for those).  There should be more of a difficulty curve, not just one-difficulty-fits-all.  Even easy-medium-hard, with set speeds for the opponents.  Let me disable BOOST if I'd like some non-boost racing.  I'd also whole-heartedly recommend a controller with analog capability not just a digital d-pad thing, as it'll be almost required to do well here.  The keyboard can be very unforgiving, but not so much so that, within an hour or two of play, that I had any trouble getting the Porsche 911 *cough* COMET *cough* around the countryside (NOT A TRACK, REAL ROADS) without an issue at top speed.  The cars handle with fairly adequete realism and also are rather forgiving when going a little 'too fast'.  There is a bit of variety here also, including desert, beaches, mountains, snow, highways (2, 4, and 6 lane highways divided and nondivided) and red-wood forest.  A few real-life vehicles are also added in for AI traffic on top of the real vehicles already present in this game for racing.  Damage is superficial and arcade-ey in nature & as such, you won't be bending your car in half.  Damage is shown by marred body panels and broken lights, and your head lights will randomly cut out while driving at night.  A bad enough head-on-collision or contact with the barrier going fast enough will show a cut-scene of your 'wonderful' ability on the road, and set you back several seconds of racing, though it is not an impossibly long time that you cannot catch up (usually).  If you are looking for a well-polished racer for SINGLEPLAYER racing, this is the game for you.  If you are looking for multiplayer, you'll have to look only to EA's newest offering as multiplayer only lives about 2-3 years AT MOST on EA's newest titles.  This is one of the serious, most deal-breaking cons there is to this game, is that EA's servers are required by the game to do multiplayer (you must log in to save).  I shouldn't have a gimped product so soon after release, especially with these financially hard times today, and that goes for anyone who buys most of their games from the bargain bin like I do.  Let us atleast host/join user-servers after you shut the official ones down.  Don't MAKE me log into ANYTHING (I don't care about cloud-saving, it's a GAME, not my job!) to play singleplayer and save.  I LOATHED GTA IV for this aspect and actually had to mod THAT game to let me save without logging in (even though I purchased it more than once for myself legally) simply because it was an annoyance.
I could go on for hours, but don't let the ranting bit fool you, it's still a fun and well-polished game.  Don't hate me if it becomes obvious that there are flaws and programming gimmicks in this game, however, with the AI always keeping up and the autolog fahl-dee-rahl.  Still way better than Rockstar games DRM-hassled lousy console-ported GTAIV/EFLC with all it's login-required-rubbish.  It's a game, I don't want to have to LOG IN, might as well just say 'anything you do in this game can be used against you in the court of law', to all the customers.
I will make it a point, that if you just want to race a Porsche or other supercar around the roads, it allows you to do so without logging in though you'd have to unlock other cars 1st.  That is about all I can do on mine here, as the game is just too hard with my PTSD to get into most times.

Pros:
Hours of Arcade Racing fun!
Fancy GFX
Fancy SFX
Always stays fairly challenging no matter what your skill level.
Real Road Racing, not closed, unrealistic tracks.

Cons:
No real damage, if that's what you're into.
Opponents scripted to always keep up, they're always right behind you no matter what (that's a game-breaker for me).
For me this ruins racing, as it also takes away your sense of accomplishment (until the race is over if you win).
Menu can be confusing to some or takes atleast some getting used to, and AUTOLOG, or any LOG INs outside of multiplayer is irritating and invasive as a means of copy-protection masquerading as a feature.  Leave this OUT, EA.
Unskippable cut scenes, that's a pain.  DON'T EVER FORCE CUT SCENES, that just sucks.
Opponents use boost ALL the time, or atleast on a consistent basis.  What if I want to disable BOOSTING on my game, what, I can't shut that off or toggle it out for my game session?
Music is OK if you're a teenager.  I am not into that type of music, nor is anyone that I know.  Where'd they find this stuff anyways?  Any way would could stream a few real-stations in-game (without using our own media player in this OS)?  I am sure some stations would like that publicity/promotion.

Good game not free of caveats, still recommend if you like EA's products, just know what you are in for, that is all.
Real opponents next time, EA.  This was a game-breaking thing for myself but that's just me.

reviewText:
Need for speed - Sellout Edition maybe.  Once upon a time NFS involved a bit of acrade-style racing that was fun.  These cars handle more like hovercraft:  If you see it, you WILL hit it.  They decided to add the popular 'it takes time to turn your steering wheel' mechanic, which, let's face it:  Is completely bonkers for a decent racing game.
I only played the police side of it, so maybe the actual 'racing' part is better, but...  I doubt it.  The physics just don't seem to support the ability to actually turn without 'drifing'.  Even at speeds greater than 150 in cars that are built to add down-force, the game designers seemed to think that drifting will still make you turn better.

In other words, the game tries too hard to be 'realistic' with it's steering/physics system while ignoring the effects of downforce on cornering, to the point that it becomes pointless to play.  Then they added a drifting mechanic to try to make up for it, which is completely unrealistic.

reviewText:
Well, we were searching for a game to play together and we stumbled over this fun little racing game. I said little because that's the truth here, there is so little to do, almost nothing. I feel like the only thing to do is playing multiplayer races. If you consider buying this, only do so if it is ON SALE. I'm giving this game a downvote because you should not have to pay money for a game this thin and dissappointing.

Pros:

-The multiplayer. You only have very few mods though, and after two days of playing you know every single racing track (like, every single one of them)
-The graphics. Definitely not top-notch but it fits the game and the lighting effects are really cool and seem realistic.
-The sounds. Nothing out of the ordinary here, the music tracks are a matter of taste. The intro is way too loud though.
-The driving. It feels nice and responsive, nothing bad about it.

Cons:

-The singleplayer. I don't think EA was sober when they made this. Its an insult.
-Stuff besides the racing. No tuning, you may only choose from some colours to spray your car in.
-The tracks. Repetitive, but not always lame, cool shortcuts but overall not enough diversity.
-(The multiplayer. As I said, its fun, but you've got so few modes that it gets boring pretty quick.)

Conclusion:

This game could have been so much more. Its a dissappointment. If you want to play a better multiplayer racing game from the NFS series, try the new Most Wanted (Singleplayer sucks here, though). The multiplayer has a whole city, cool modes and is just way more interactive when playing with friends. So, don't buy Hot Pursuit, better get Most Wanted or something else because this here is not what I would call a good game.

reviewText: This game has terrific graphics and cars, and, unlike some games, the cars actually have their real life badges. You take a gamble with the price but it's worth it. I've played a totall of 36 hours (so far) and I'm already extremly good at driving. The original controls are a bit strange but it's easy to change them to your liking. Seacrest County is a large county with winding roads that take you through Wintery Mountains, Burning Deserts, Rich Beaches, Beautiful Lakes, and much more. With two careers (SCPD & Racer) avaliable simultaneously it provides hours of fun and some of the world's best cars (Including my favorite, the Nissan GT-R SpecV) from the Ford Crown Victoria to the Bugatti Veyron and more between. Cars are relatively easy to unlock and, instead of buying them, you just unlock them at stages based on the bounty you earn. One of the best racing games with realistic roads where no two sections are the same.

reviewText:
This was one of the first modern racing games I played. I hadn't played a racing game in quite a while beforehand.
.. and I was disappointed. I remember playing Hot Pursuit 2 in the past on the Gamecube? or some console around that time and it was pretty cool.. it had good visuals for its time, an awesome soundtrack, fun levels, and a great car selection complete with the ability to freely set up tracks and play as you want alone or with friends. That was a cool game.

This one isn't.

Visually it looks good. The music is.. meh. The music is boring. The title or level select screens don't have that awesome upbeat style the older Hot Pursuit games did. Its so dark and boring.

The actual levels have a limited selection of vehicles of choice. The sense of speed is pretty good, but the levels are very very basic. Despite being a more arcadey game, it kind of felt like you should just play a racing simulator instead.
Its like, a weird in-between of arcadey awesome and simulation and fails to deliver on either.
There are some more arcadey game modes where you drop spike traps and things like that and they're just boring. Being chased by cops is dull.

The whole game is incredibly bland. Oh, and there isn't even a free-play mode where you choose a level and any car you
want + other settings like cops on or off, difficulty, and a bunch of other things the old NFS games had.
Yeah, that doesn't exist at all. There's multiplayer but I never tried it. All you get is a singleplayer campaign with no story and limitations.

Maybe I didn't give it enough of a chance but I found myself tired of it too early on to keep playing.
This game just isn't very good and there are much better racing games out there.

reviewText:
When I was a wee little kid one of my first racing games was Need for Speed 3: Hot Pursuit. It was fun. The way the title was written I always thought it was Need for Speed Hot Pursuit 3, and so I wondered why Hot Pursuit 2 was better in every way, but it was fun. Then I got Hot Pursuit 2 on PC AND PS2 because it was that freaking good. I played the crap out of that game, and it was always fun to return home from school to race while avoiding the police.

What seperates Hot Pursuit from other racing games? The cops. In Need for Speed: Hot Pursuit, not only are you racing other cars, but you also have to worry about the police who will do everything in their power to shut the race down. This includes slamming your car all over the road, pinning it into corners, setting up roadblocks ahead, dropping spikestrips to flatten your tires, and calling a helicopter to find ways to ensure that even in the air they can ruin your day. It's not just a racing game, but an action survival game as you wreck cop cars and escape from the police like it's Fast and Furious. Which like the movies, Need for Speed is all about the rule of cool trope. Why is that cop chasing you in a Lamborghini? Because it's awesome, that's why.

At the time this game came out I thought Need for Speed was a dead franchise. I had no idea this game and others existed. I only recently found out about this some months ago, and waited for a sale to pick this up. Now I was hesitant to get this reboot of the series considering what happened when Red Alert 3 was made (to make a long story short, it wasn't very good, and Red Alert 2 was one of my favorite games from my childhood as well), so I came in with low expectations. But holy cow was I ever surprised that they didn't mess this game up.

It's still Hot Pursuit. But, it's Hot Pursuit on crack! Let me go over some of the differences between Hot Pursuit 2 and this game.

1) In Hot Pursuit 2, the police had no way to bust you other than to be within a certain distance for a certain amount of time while you are below a certain speed. Once they do this three times, you're out of the race. In this reboot, rather than having strikes you have a health bar. All the cops (as well as other racers, pedestrians, and the enviroment) have to do is destroy your car. Granted your health is fairly beefy, but it IS possible to take down to zero, and in later parts of the game this happened quite frequently. This is a welcome change as it makes good driving skills much more important, as well as easing the OP'ness of the racers.
2) In Hot Pursuit 2, spikestrips were static. A cop would request permission to place it, get approved, and then one would spawn ahead in a set location. The police would then announce on the radio where it was and what side of the road it was on. It was essentially a less visible roadblock. In Hot Pursuit 2010 the racers AND police have spikestrips, and they are deployables. When playing offline, I never noticed other racers using spikestrips, but that was fine by me as the police did more than fill that gap. What a cop will do is drive ahead of you, pull out in front, and then drop a strip. So if you see a cop pass you by, try to get as far away from the back of his car as possible. This makes spikestrips much more interesting as they can be anywhere at anytime, and you have to be able to adapt. It's never impossible to dodge them, but it does get trickier as you progress, because all gadgets" have upgrades. So that means a cop may drop multiple strips.
3) Gadgets. Hot Pursuit 2 had you and the cars. This game

reviewText:
TL;DR
It's ok, very arcade-y and basic, not for people who want deep customization like NFS UG, I recommend buying
Need for Speed Undercover if you want a more free-form racing experience, however this is also great fun for what it is,
and a steal for $5

LONG AND READ

Pros
Pursuits are actually engaging unlike past NFS games: The cops are just as fast (or faster) than you, and also have the same gadgets
Maps are nice and open with plenty of shortcuts to explore
Crashing isn't a total loss; you can easily recover
Raceways are extremely gorgeous to look at
Neutrals
Cars handle realistically, so if you're accustomed to extremely tight turning, you'll be disappointed
Easier than most NFS's
Very arcade-like: No story to be found
Dead multiplayer (personally I don't care)
Cons
EXTREMELY limited car customization: Can only pick from a set number of stock colors
No stat performance upgrades
Stats are extremely basic [ex. Max Speed & 0-100 (kph)/ 0-60 (mph)]
Car list is pretty disappointing compared to Undercover
Time trial times are extremely tight, requiring perfect driving + shortcuts to get a good time

Overall, I would recommend it, but it's aimed towards casual players, and is not difficult in any sense. It's extremely easy
to pick up, and easy to put down. It's great for what it is, but I feel like paying $20 is a bit too much. If you find it for $5,
it's well worth the price. A fun game that doesn't overstay its welcome, and hey, there's even two campaigns". Also it's pretty awesome to see a police Pagani Zonda."

reviewText:
The main issue I have with this game is that it is focused on on-line gaming. I suppose that the game was alright durign the few months after its launch at end of 2010. There are not so many players around 2014, I am afraid. The game makes matchmaking even more difficult than what it should: you need to chose between game type and car type before you enter a lobby. There is no indication how lively online gaming is, although I have been able to play a single game. On a saturday afternoon.

As far as the single player campaing go, the game is somewhat boring. I played the game with an XBox360 pad and I can tell you I have not let the throttle go. It is an arcade racer. You start with already fast cars, taking many bends at 200 kmh, and cars only get faster, or harder to control. That means that many bends are wide enough, so the challenges end up being the off-road sections. It looks like there is some sort of mechanism to correct your direction too.

Campaign setup is devoid of interesting things to do. You play both a lifeless policeman and a lifeless racer, with only a mention that police forces try to stop the racers at Seacrest County. There is no story of any sort, not even the dumbest story you could think of (a la NfS: Underground 2). The reward system also gets into my nerves, as almost any race you run is followed by a 20 to 60 second slideshow showing you your rewards. Rewards that you do not care because there are so many of them, and many are just the ones that you forget of next race. I have been driving a new car each race.

On the technical side, I would have expected some sort of antialiasing in the game. The game is OK by being a port from Xbox360/PS3, with graphics matching what you can do on the consoles. That means, graphics show its age if you know where you are looking for.

Game requires an Origin account for its online component. The original Autolog website is gone, replaced by a NFS:Rivals only website. I wonder how much life is left for this game, as EA is notorious of turning off the multiplayer servers after a while.

So, if you get some friends playing this game, you might enjoy far way better than a solo player than me.

reviewText:
Updated review 02/01-15:

A very enjoyable racing game. There's normal races, hot pursuit, 1v1 duels, and time trials.  Wide variety of sexy licenced vehicles to drive. Looks great for its age with optional HD textures.

The car handling feels great if you like drifting, the vehicles feel heavy and going sideways through the turns at high speeds just feels good.  All the cars behave very different as well, from the Bentleys that feel like you're driving a tank, to the super responsive Pagani, each suited for different races and game modes.

Features Autolog, an early iteration of the social features we take for granted in today's games.  Its a bit fiddly and requires an EA account, of course not linked to Steam, but with some friends added it gives the singleplayer modes a competitive edge thanks to the Speedwall.

To get the most out of this game you need to find people to race online, but except during Steam sales there's not many playing. See http://steamcharts.com/app/47870#3m for details.  At least the servers are still running which is more than can be said for Gran Turismo 5, for example.

If you're not bothered with multiplayer, there's still fun to be had here but playing through the 'campaign' won't hold you for that many hours.

If you use Windows 8.1 be warned, you might run into nasty frame drops.

reviewText:
I must say that I was unpleasantly surprised by this title in the Need For Speed series. Luckily I bought it during a Steam Sale. I've finished the game in a less than 10 hours (probably even a hour or 2 less as I go AFK mid-games sometimes) without any struggling, and I'm not a professional when it comes to racing games. But most importantly: there is no reason to come back and play it again at all after completing the ''campaign''. After finishing the campaign, you unlock every car automatically and there is nothing else you can work towards to (there even aren't any Steam achievements). There is an option to play online against other players, but there aren't enough (if any) other players for this game anymore and therefore the racing against others online option is dead. You can queue for an online game, wait a hour, and still find out that none else will join it. You can also compare your racing-times with other players, but only with friends who also happen to play the game. How ridiculous is that?! You also can't customize the easily-earned cars, except for picking a new full-body color for only some cars, unlike other games in the NFS-series including NFS: Undercover. As for the positive factors, that would mostly be the graphics and crash-scenes. I wouldn't ever buy this game for over ‚Ç¨ 5,-. Even for a ‚Ç¨ 5,- price-tag I'd still have my thoughts whether it's worth it. Anyway, here is my list of pros and cons with a bit of extra stuff in it.

Pros:
- Great graphics
- Great crashing-scenes
- Great police-chases and escapes (helicopter interceptions, barricades, awesome!)
- You can destroy other cars (so can yours be)
- Easily learnt how to play it

Cons:
- Every. single. car. is automatically and easily earned by finishing the not-challenging-at-all campaign (only the final 2 missions are a bit challenging, though still easy)
- No customization options (only some cars can get a different full-body paint-job, that's all.) (There also isn't even a single customization option for the police cars)
- There is a leveling system which has no purpose at all. I think it's only there to make you feel like you still earned something after losing a race (which you will rarely lose). The leveling system offers you slightly upgraded (and no different) weapons for your car. You will earn those ''upgraded'' weapons automatically during the campaign anyway.
- Racing-routes are getting used over and over during the campaign, not once, not twice, no, sometimes you're driving the same road for up to like 8 different missions.
- Racing-routes all look somewhat the same. No special jumps or whatsoever. Just one route has more curves than the others.
- You play as two different roles during the entire game. Sometimes as the police officer, sometimes as the wanted person. But both roles earn the exact same car, except that you get sirens when being the police officer. Worst of all, because of that, you earn every single car in the game twice. So you've finished a mission, and what is your reward? ''Oh hey, it's the Lamborghini again which I've won earlier in this campaign as well, just this time with sirens on its roof''.
- Sometimes the weather changes into a thunderstorm, but the amount of lightning during the thunderstorms is ridiculous. Lightning flashes every second. (awful if you're seizure-sensitive)
- The online community is completely dead. Barely anyone plays the game online, sometimes you can sit in a queue (room) for up a to a hour and still not see any other player.
- There is also no reason to play online, it does not earn you anything and you can't compare your stats with other online players. You can only compare your stats with friends.
- There is nothing else to work towards to after finishing the campaign, there even aren't any Steam achievements, and there is no point in trying to set a better racing-time as you can't compare the stats online.
- The physics are different (awful?) compared to the other NFS titles. You will (almost) never get off the ground with your car, no matter how big the bump in the road is. There are 2 or 3 bumps in the entire game (which you can even skip) which gets you only slightly off the ground, but you won't even notice that if you blinked. Steering also works awful compared to the other NFS titles. If you steer for a millisecond and tap the brake for a millisecond, you can get through any curve and you can perform a burn-out for the rest of the race. The only way to get out of the burnout is by driving 99% straight forward. If you're steering even slightly (10%) left or right, you'll stay in a burnout.
- When you crash, you actually don't crash. A cut-scene with a crash pops up whenever you hit something else hard enough, and once the cut-scene ends you're just somehow driving at full speed and perfectly straight on the road.
- Campaign is very repetitive. You'll barely notice any difference between the first mission, the final mission and everything in between.
- Every mission uses the exact same cut-scene, both at the start and in the end.
- (small con) When you start up the game, you have to sit through some of the credits and wait for them to pass by; you can't skip them.
- You can abuse bugs by crashing your car at certain moments. For example, if there is a roadblock up ahead, you can 1 mile beforehand hit the guardrail to trigger a crashing cut-scene; the crashing cut-scene lets you completely bypass the roadblock.
- The game can be finished within a few hours, even if you're entirely new to racing games. There is no reason to come back unless you'd like to start the campaign over again

Out of 10, I'd rate it 5,5. The awesome police-chases and escapes is what compensates it just enough to be able to say that ''it's an ok game''. But I'm excluding the price for that rating. If I'd include the price, I'd definitely not recommend it to others. The amount of hours you can/will spend on this game simply isn't worth ‚Ç¨ 15,-. It'd be ‚Ç¨ 5,- max. But if you ''just want to try'' this game out, I wouldn't even pay ‚Ç¨ 5,-. Do it if you're a NFS-fan who's truly interested or otherwise get any of the other (even older) NFS titles. And if you really want police-chases, get the older, better, and cheaper NFS Undercover instead.

reviewText:
Lets break this review into mulitple parts:

Graphics: Seems like they only tried to make the cars look good, but the map and surroundings is made up of picilated, terrible quality graphics.

Racing: Not much of a learning curve at all. No manual transmission, only control over your car that you have is steering and braking. Thats it.

User Interface: The menu system is built like an old arcade game style or console style. No mouse. Makes it annoying to scroll through lists like your controls, which half the time break if you accidentally bind two things to the same key. Another thing is that you have to be connected to the internet for your progress to be saved, and if you reinstall the game your progress isnt even linked to your account, so you have to start over from scratch (lost ~20 hours of gameplay).

Music: Rather short playlist and starts to get repetitive about 2 hours into the game. I just turn it off and play music from youtube.

Multiplayer: Dead. Dont buy this game just to play with your friends since it will only be you and your pals in the whole server system.


Overall rating: 3/10. Dont buy this game, Dont fund EA, even if this game is on sale. Youl have more fun with other racing sims.

reviewText:
Overall this game fails due to the cheating rubber band AI. Why have faster cars when the AI will cheat and fly past you with a slower car? Despite all the cheating to AI fails to provide much of a challenge. Sometimes the AI will even get so high speed boost into a corner, that they have no chance of making the turn and instead wall ride / bounce of the walls to make the turn.

Some of the negative things I faced in this game:

The way takedowns of opponents and cops can cause some really annoying and confusing situations. Sometimes I'd bust racers as a cop, when after a previous cutscene spawned me directly on a crash course with another racer. Coming out of a crash cutscene can also cause you to be heading towards a wall with almost no time to recover. The way these crashes get triggered also seems quite random at times. Sometimes you'll be crashing with traffic almost head on at 200km/h only to have your speed reduced. Other times hitting something at much lower speed will trigger a crash.

Taking down cops as a racer also seems to be quite pointless. In many cases the game will simply spawn more and more cops to chase you, thus turning the takedowns into nothing more but some extra points for advancing your rank.

The handling differences of the cars within a certain series are basically nonexistent. Sure, this isn't meant to be a simulation, but it would be nice if your car selection would have any impact on the handling at all. Now they all feel basically the same.

I also randomly experienced some odd performance slowdowns  that fixed themselves after a couple of seconds.

Positive things about the game:

Unlike many other modern NFS games, this does actually have a bonnet  camera. Thus you aren't forced to use the back camera like in many other games in the series. Yes, those games do have the bumper camera, but I consider that to be useless as it's so low that you cannot see anything even if there's a slighthest hill on the road.

You can turn of the damn siren, even during a chase event. There's no point in having it on IMHO since it has no effect on the traffic anyway. For example some events in Rivals force you to have the siren on.

The soundtrack is decent enough. It does have some really good tracks like Watercolour by Pendulum.

There aren't long unskippable cutscenes, I wish though that those that are in the game could be skipped.

reviewText:
While this game has high production values if you come to it expecting a realistic pursuit simulator you are in the wrong place. Thanks in large part to an over emphasis on driving as quickly as you can without any real motivation the game ends up feeling contrived and unsatisfying.

As a police interceptor the goal is to stop cars by wrecking them. If you manage to stop a car by pinning them to a mountain or wall for instance, then the car will simply respawn on the road and continue as normal. In races not as the police, ai cars don't rubberband, they warp.

If you don't have access to a gamepad, or preferably a steeringwheel accessory then I recomend you skip this title without a second thought. Keyboard controls are overly responsive without any ability to modulate the controls or their sensitivity making the game not an arcade racer, but more like a pinball simulator.

If you are pinning for the Need for Speed Hot Pursuit of the late 90's, give this title a pass. If, however, you just want a racer where you can take down cars and smash up the competition then give this title a pass, and go acquire Burnout Paradise. Despite the lack of support and the frankly irresponsible take down of the DLC store, it is still a far supperior title with far more replayability and far less repetition.

Final Verdict

Grand Turismo on Ice

reviewText:
8.8/10
According to most of the reviews online, this is one of the best Need For Speed games in the series, and I couldn't agree more. Criterion has done a great job (if not, a better job than EA) making this masterpiece. The game is very much back to its roots. It's much like the first generation of games in the franchise. The fact that Criterion was in charge in making this game proved that EA and/or Black Box are fond of making too much changes to the game, therefore dissapointing fans. Criterion knows well what the fans want.

The game may start a bit slow but as you progress throughout your career (as a racer or cop), it gets faster and better. It also gives you certain types of equipment to help cope with the sh** load of challenges in Career mode.

I know this game is pretty old but it's still worth playing. Seriously, I was paranoid when I bought the game with the leftover $20 I had, anxious that it wouldn't be worth the 20 bucks. Need For Speed Hot Pursuit definitely proved me wrong.

I made this recmmendation hoping that I'd get more friends to play the game. Single player isn't the only feature in this game and I'd love to try out more WITH friends.

Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
I've played many NFS series games, including the first ones, and this is probably the worst one. I bought this game because I wanted a car racing game and I recalled the fun I had playing cops and running from them previously. This title doesn't deliver at all.

NFS: Hot Pursuit has only one good thing about it - a variety of cars. But it doesn't matter as every car feels the same since this game has no proper physics at all. Cars stick to the road as if glued, you bounce from the walls like a ball and even the engine sound is average. The game has no soul, no emotion, getting a new car after every race is not exciting at all. Just boring.

Maybe if you're into 100% arcade and don't expect much - you might like it. But if you're into cars and even slightly demanding races - stay away, or you'll be just as disappointed as I was.

reviewText: If you are familiar with NFS games then you are familiar with the fact that they are arcade racers. What sets an arcade racer apart from a game like Gran Turismo or Grid is that the control of the car is very unrealistic. Now, in previous games in the NFS canon that was not too bad. However, in this game, I honestly felt like the game was driving for me. At points you simply hit the break button once before a turn and the game takes over driving for the rest of the turn. Also, the stats that are assigned to each car regarding their top speed and zero to sixty time mean next to nothing regarding how the car will function in the game. You can continually put the cars which are faster than other cars up against each other, and the computer will just pull its ahead so that it can give the illusion of compeitition. Top speeds mean nothing because the nitrous feature eradicates whatever top speed you had. Also, the camera is constantly ripped from your grasp when you crash, when you crash another car or when one of your traps hits another car. Thus, again the computer takes over driving and will just randomly stick you somewhere in the road when it ends the crash cut scene. This can be particularly frustrating when you wreck and your car spends in the air for a few seconds before coming to a stop and the game then just restarts you somewhere back in the pack. Those criticisms aside, this is one of the better racing games available on steam. The GRID games are agonizingly realistic and PC lacks the GT or Forza games. Still though, this game does not measure up to the classic NFS games such as Hot Pursuit 2 and Underground. This game feels more about just showing off graphics then actual gameplay.

Overall:  9/10.  Grab some friends, and have fun racing and totally wrecking hundred-thousand-dollar vehicles.
